There are two types of pain during labour: visceral and somatic. During the first phase of labour, uterine contractions lead to the cervix collapsing and dilating, and the visceral pain impulse is carried by non-myelinated C fibres. Pain specific to contractions is handled by Aδ fibres. These two types of fibre relay to the posterior horn of the spinal cord from T10 to L1. At the end of the first phase and during the second phase of labour, pain of somatic origin appears secondary to distension of the pelvic floor, vagina and perineum and is transmitted by the pudendal nerves originating from the sacral roots S2-S4.

question.title: What type of nerve fibers transmit visceral pain during the first phase of labour?
question.description: During the first phase of labour, what type of nerve fibers transmit visceral pain?

option_a.title: Aδ fibres
option_a.description: A type of nerve fiber that transmits pain specific to contractions

option_b.title: Pudendal nerves
option_b.description: Nerves that transmit pain from the pelvic floor, vagina, and perineum

option_c.title: C fibres
option_c.description: Nerve fibers that transmit pain from the cervix and uterus

option_d.title: Somatic nerve fibers
option_d.description: Nerve fibers that transmit pain from the pelvic floor, vagina, and perineum

correct_option.title: C
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the answer
